message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Safe Learning in Robotics: From Learning-Based Control to Safe Reinforcement Learning
Paper Abstract: The last half decade has seen a steep rise in the number of contributions on safe learning methods for real-world robotic deployments from both the control and reinforcement learning communities. This article provides a concise but holistic review of the recent advances made in using machine learning to achieve safe decision-making under uncertainties, with a focus on unifying the language and frameworks used in control theory and reinforcement learning research. It includes learning-based control approaches that safely improve performance by learning the uncertain dynamics, reinforcement learning approaches that encourage safety or robustness, and methods that can formally certify the safety of a learned control policy. As data- and learning-based robot control methods continue to gain traction, researchers must understand when and how to best leverage them in real-world scenarios where safety is imperative, such as when operating in close proximityto humans. We highlight some of the open challenges that will drive the field of robot learning in the coming years, and emphasize the need for realistic physics-based benchmarks to facilitate fair comparisons between control and reinforcement learning approaches.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's what I found about Robotics:

## Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics focuses on the design and construction of physical robot structures, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components

Robotics combines three aspects of design work: mechanical construction, electrical components that power and control machinery, and software programs that determine how and when a robot performs actions.

## Types and Applications

The field encompasses diverse robot types and applications:

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials instead of rigid links, and the compliance of soft robots can improve their safety when working in close contact with humans.

- **Hexapod Robots**: A hexapod robot is a mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs, and has a great deal of flexibility in how it can move.

- **Diverse Applications**: Robots range from humanoids such as Honda's ASIMO and TOSY's Ping Pong Playing Robot to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, and UAV drones.

## Industry Growth

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

I found comprehensive search results on machine learning. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms: supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning, with each corresponding to a particular learning task.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Historical Background

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Neural Networks

In machine learning, a neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks, consisting of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons.

The search results included detailed information about attention mechanisms, computational learning theory, and various historical developments in machine learning technology.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about adaptive control:

## General Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.(no content)Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Categories

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.(no content)Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Categories

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Here are the search results for "Reinforcement learning":

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

Reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Characteristics

Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

## Applications

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Subfields

The search results also revealed several important subfields and related techniques:

- **Deep Reinforcement Learning**: Deep reinforcement learning combines reinforcement learning and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

- **Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF)**: RLHF is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences, involving training a reward model to represent preferences which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

- **Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning**: Multi-agent reinforcement learning is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Control theory is routinely applied to problems in both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

Web search results for query: "Feedback control"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Control–feedback–abort loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control%E2%80%93feedback%E2%80%93abort_loop"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"}]

Here are the search results for "Feedback control":

## Overview

A feedback control system is a system which tends to maintain a prescribed relationship of one system variable to another by comparing functions of these variables and using the difference as a means of control.(no content)A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller, and uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Common Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Types of Control

Fundamentally, there are two types of control loop: open-loop control (feedforward), and closed-loop control (feedback).(no content)Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Control–feedback–abort loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control%E2%80%93feedback%E2%80%93abort_loop"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"}]

Here are the search results for "Feedback control":

## Overview

A feedback control system is a system which tends to maintain a prescribed relationship of one system variable to another by comparing functions of these variables and using the difference as a means of control.(no content)A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller, and uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Common Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Types of Control

Fundamentally, there are two types of control loop: open-loop control (feedforward), and closed-loop control (feedback).(no content)Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

Web search results for query: "Safety in robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Workplace robotics safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workplace_robotics_safety"},{"title":"Robotic tech vest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_tech_vest"},{"title":"Vecna Technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vecna_Technologies"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Velodyne Lidar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velodyne_Lidar"},{"title":"Waukesha South High School - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waukesha_South_High_School"},{"title":"Heavy equipment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering_vehicle"},{"title":"1X Technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1X_Technologies"}]

## Summary of Search Results for "Safety in Robotics"

I found comprehensive information about safety in robotics. Here are the key findings:

### Workplace Robotics Safety

Workplace robotics safety is an aspect of occupational safety and health when robots are used in the workplace.(no content)This includes traditional industrial robots as well as emerging technologies such as drone aircraft and wearable robotic exoskeletons.

### Types of Hazards and Injuries

Types of accidents include collisions, crushing, and injuries from mechanical parts.(no content)Fifty-six percent of robot injuries are classified as pinch injuries and 44% of injuries are classified as impact injuries.(no content)A 1987 study found that line workers are at the greatest risk, followed by maintenance workers, and programmers.

### Safety Controls and Measures

Hazard controls include physical barriers, good work practices, and proper maintenance.(no content)One common safeguard used in industrial settings is the installation of robot safety fencing. These barriers, often made from durable materials such as mesh or polycarbonate, prevent accidental interactions between workers and robotic systems, reducing the risk of injury.

### Innovative Safety Technology

Robots can sense a vest from a distance and avoid moving into it, thus protecting the wearer from collisions. In 2018, Amazon introduced robotic tech vests in 25 warehouses to protect workers from robot collisions.

### Standards and Oversight

Safety standards are being developed by the Robotic Industries Association (RIA) in conjunction with the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).(no content)NIOSH launched the Center for Occupational Robotics Research to "provide scientific leadership to guide the development and use of occupational robots that enhance worker safety, health, and well being".

Links: [{"title":"System dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_dynamics"},{"title":"Earth System Dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth_System_Dynamics"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Category:Dynamics of the Solar System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Dynamics_of_the_Solar_System"},{"title":"Cardiovascular System Dynamics Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiovascular_System_Dynamics_Society"},{"title":"Conservative system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_system"},{"title":"Graph dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Projected dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projected_dynamical_system"},{"title":"General Dynamics European Land Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Dynamics_European_Land_Systems"},{"title":"Max Planck Institute for Dynamics of Complex Technical Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Dynamics_of_Complex_Technical_Systems"}]

Here are the search results for "System dynamics":

## Definition and Overview

System dynamics (SD) is an approach to understanding the nonlinear behaviour of complex systems over time using stocks, flows, internal feedback loops, table functions and time delays.(no content)System dynamics is a mathematical modeling technique to frame, understand, and discuss complex systems.

## History and Development

System dynamics was created during the mid-1950s by Professor Jay Forrester of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.(no content)Forrester's insights into the common foundations that underlie engineering, which led to the creation of system dynamics, were triggered, to a large degree, by his involvement with managers at General Electric (GE) during the mid-1950s. At that time, the managers at GE were perplexed because employment at their appliance plants in Kentucky exhibited a significant three-year cycle. From hand simulations of the stock-flow-feedback structure of the GE plants, which included the existing corporate decision-making structure for hiring and layoffs, Forrester was able to show how the instability in GE employment was due to the internal structure of the firm and not to an external force such as the business cycle.(no content)During the late 1950s and early 1960s, Forrester and a team of graduate students moved the emerging field of system dynamics from the hand-simulation stage to the formal computer modeling stage. Richard Bennett created the first system dynamics computer modeling language called SIMPLE (Simulation of Industrial Management Problems with Lots of Equations) in the spring of 1958.

## Key Concept

It is a property of complex systems that the structure of any system, with many circular, interlocking, sometimes time-delayed relationships among its components, is often just as important in determining its behavior as the individual components themselves.

Links: [{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Quantification of margins and uncertainties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantification_of_margins_and_uncertainties"},{"title":"Talk:Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Uncertainty analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_analysis"},{"title":"Talk:Numerical methods for partial differential equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Numerical_partial_differential_equations"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Climate change/Figures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Climate_change/Figures"},{"title":"Talk:Info-gap decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Info-gap_decision_theory"},{"title":"Oil and gas reserves and resource quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingent_resources"},{"title":"Integrated Carbon Observation System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Carbon_Observation_System"}]

## Uncertainty Quantification

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications.(no content)It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

### Key Concepts

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sources of uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

### Types of Uncertainty

Aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty can occur simultaneously, and in real life applications, both kinds of uncertainties are present. Uncertainty quantification intends to explicitly express both types of uncertainty separately.

### Approaches

Existing uncertainty propagation approaches include probabilistic and non-probabilistic approaches. Probabilistic approaches include simulation-based methods such as Monte Carlo simulations, importance sampling, and adaptive sampling, as well as general surrogate-based methods where a surrogate model is learnt to replace the experiment or simulation with a cheap and fast approximation.

## Uncertainty Quantification

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications.(no content)It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

### Key Concepts

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sources of uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

### Types of Uncertainty

Aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty can occur simultaneously, and in real life applications, both kinds of uncertainties are present. Uncertainty quantification intends to explicitly express both types of uncertainty separately.

### Approaches

Existing uncertainty propagation approaches include probabilistic and non-probabilistic approaches. Probabilistic approaches include simulation-based methods such as Monte Carlo simulations, importance sampling, and adaptive sampling, as well as general surrogate-based methods where a surrogate model is learnt to replace the experiment or simulation with a cheap and fast approximation.

Here are the search results for "Human-robot interaction":

## Overview

Human–robot interaction (HRI) is the study of interactions between humans and robots.(no content)Human–robot interaction is a multidisciplinary field with contributions from human–computer interaction, artificial intelligence, robotics, natural language processing, design, psychology and philosophy.

## Key Focus Areas

Generally, human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.(no content)Although initially robots in the human–robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, research has expanded this to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common than in the early 2000s, including simultaneous localization and mapping systems and natural-language processing systems.

## Applications

Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, and human augmentation.

## Physical Interaction

The subfield of physical human–robot interaction (pHRI) has largely focused on device design to enable people to safely interact with robotic systems, but is increasingly developing algorithmic approaches in an attempt to support fluent and expressive interactions between humans and robotic systems.

## Collaboration

Human-Robot Collaboration is the study of collaborative processes where human and robot agents work together to achieve shared goals, with many new applications for robots requiring them to work alongside people as capable members of human-robot teams.

Human-robot interaction is an active area of research with numerous applications across industrial, medical, and social domains.

Here are the search results for "Optimal control":

## Overview

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.

## Examples and Applications

For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure.(no content)Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

## Key Concepts

Optimal control deals with the problem of finding a control law for a given system such that a certain optimality criterion is achieved. A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.(no content)The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Related Approaches

The search results also reveal several related areas, including stochastic control, which is a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system, and Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP), also known as approximate dynamic programming or neuro-dynamic programming, which is a machine learning control method that combines reinforcement learning with dynamic programming to solve optimal control problems for complex systems.

Here's what I found about Model Predictive Control:

## Overview

Model predictive control (MPC) is an advanced method of process control that is used to control a process while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Model predictive controllers rely on dynamic models of the process, most often linear empirical models obtained by system identification.

## History and Applications

It has been in use in the process industries in chemical plants and oil refineries since the 1980s.(no content)In recent years it has also been used in power system balancing models and in power electronics.

## How It Works

MPC models predict the change in the dependent variables of the modeled system that will be caused by changes in the independent variables. MPC uses the current plant measurements, the current dynamic state of the process, the MPC models, and the process variable targets and limits to calculate future changes in the dependent variables. These changes are calculated to hold the dependent variables close to target while honoring constraints on both independent and dependent variables.(no content)The MPC typically sends out only the first change in each independent variable to be implemented, and repeats the calculation when the next change is required.

## Advantages Over Traditional Control

The additional complexity of the MPC control algorithm is not generally needed to provide adequate control of simple systems, which are often controlled well by generic PID controllers. Common dynamic characteristics that are difficult for PID controllers include large time delays and high-order dynamics.

## Linear vs. Nonlinear MPC

Linear MPC approaches are used in the majority of applications with the feedback mechanism of the MPC compensating for prediction errors due to structural mismatch between the model and the process.(no content)The process can be controlled with nonlinear MPC that uses a nonlinear model directly in the control application.

Web search results for query: "Formal verification software"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"KeY - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KeY"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Dafny - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dafny"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Software verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification"},{"title":"Tamarin Prover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamarin_Prover"},{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Software assurance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_Assurance"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of formal verification software:

## What is Formal Verification?

Formal verification is the use of software tools to prove properties of a formal specification, or to prove that a formal model of a system implementation satisfies its specification.

## Key Approaches and Techniques

Subareas of formal verification include deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.(no content)Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model.

## Notable Formal Verification Tools

Several important formal verification software tools exist:

- **KeY**: KeY is a formal verification tool for Java programs that accepts specifications written in the Java Modeling Language to Java source files.

- **Dafny**: Dafny is an imperative and functional compiled language that compiles to other programming languages, such as C#, Java, JavaScript, Go, and Python, and supports formal specification through preconditions, postconditions, loop invariants, loop variants, termination specifications and read/write framing specifications.

- **Tamarin Prover**: Tamarin Prover is a computer software program for formal verification of cryptographic protocols that has been used to verify Transport Layer Security 1.3, ISO/IEC 9798, DNP3 Secure Authentication v5, WireGuard, and the PQ3 Messaging Protocol of Apple iMessage.

## Applications

Prominent examples of verified software systems include the CompCert verified C compiler and the seL4 high-assurance operating system kernel.(no content)At present, formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.

## Search Results for "Human Robot Interaction"

I've found comprehensive information about human-robot interaction. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Scope

Human–robot interaction (HRI) is the study of interactions between humans and robots.(no content)It is a multidisciplinary field with contributions from human–computer interaction, artificial intelligence, robotics, natural language processing, design, psychology and philosophy.

### Key Areas and Applications

Generally human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.(no content)Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation.

### Recent Advances

Although initially robots in the human–robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, research has expanded to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common than in the early 2000s, including simultaneous localization and mapping systems and natural-language processing systems.

### Physical and Social Interaction

The subfield of physical human–robot interaction (pHRI) has largely focused on device design to enable people to safely interact with robotic systems, but is increasingly developing algorithmic approaches to support fluent and expressive interactions.

### Related Research Area: Android Science

Android science is an interdisciplinary framework for studying human interaction and cognition based on the premise that a very humanlike robot can elicit human-directed social responses in human beings.

The search results also include information about notable researchers in the field, historical robot projects, and examples of HRI applications and experiments.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Safe Learning in Robotics: From Learning-Based Control to Safe Reinforcement Learning". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review of existing methods)

**Triples Extracted:** 10 key technologies and methodologies

The analysis identified and validated the following entities from the title and abstract:

1. **Robotics** - The primary domain of application
2. **Machine learning** - Core technique for safe decision-making
3. **Reinforcement learning** - A key learning approach reviewed
4. **Control theory** - Framework unified with RL in the paper
5. **Optimal control** - Method for safe performance improvement
6. **Model predictive control** - Learning-based control approach
7. **Adaptive control** - Method for learning uncertain dynamics
8. **Formal verification** - For certifying safety of policies
9. **Uncertainty quantification** - For safe decision-making under uncertainty
10. **Human-robot interaction** - Application domain for safe learning

Each triple includes:
- Entity name and type (task, method, or concept)
- Relation to the paper (uses)
- Wikipedia URL
- 1-sentence relevance statement

All validation checks passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics)
- [Machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)
- [Reinforcement learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Optimal control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control)
- [Model predictive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Formal verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)
- [Uncertainty quantification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification)
- [Human-robot interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-robot_interaction)
